div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin March 29th 1916
div1.p:
I received your sweet letter this morning — the letter you wrote when you thought Betty was dead. You have a wonderful character. You put yourself "in rapport" with one so beautifully. Of course I’m very happy now, having believed Betty dead and finding her living. The reaction has been so great that I’m filled with joy in spite of the fact that the little girl is so seriously wounded. You see that having believed her dead and finding her living overshadows everything else. The only trouble is not being
able to get any news. Winereux is in the army zone and no wires can go through. In the paper this morning (La France of Bordeaux) I noted that the Professor expected to return to Paris in a few days. That is of course encouraging and means that his daughter is expected to recover.

Do you know I’m rather pleased that the notice in the Herald anent the 7,000 feet fall of the aeroplane [sic] made you worry about me. No. I’m not guilty. It was a fellow named Le Comte that fell. He was an elive pilote and making an altitude. He fainted, or went wrong someway [sic], at the height. Of course the paper got it all wrong. He wasn’t on a fast machine. He was on a Bleriot.
Then again the machine wasn’t saved. It was broken to bits. Haviland, who was the first to reach him, after picking out the pilot, pulled out a stancion of the cabine that was embedded two feet in the earth. That was all that was left of the plane. The pilot was of course very fortunate not to have been killed — the machine landed on its back — but it was a miracle. Just to night one of the fellows has returned from seeing him at the hospital. His hair has turned grey. His eyes have a dull, senseless look, and he does not recollect much of his former life. He does not know who he is, and he stoops. And when he stoops his mouth opens and he looks silly.
They say he will always stoop. Considering it all in all it might have been better had he been killed the way another fellow was that same day — on the spot. I wonder if Betty will have any permanent injury.

closer.salute: Good night Marcelle and God bless you.
